awd_titl_txt: The Role of Dwarf-Dwarf Galaxy Interactions Over Cosmic Time
awd_abstract_narration:
According to current understanding, large galaxies like our Milky Way are built through the merging together of smaller, dwarf galaxies, and yet research into these important merging events is still mostly uncharted territory. The numbers of known dwarfs in the nearby universe is about to sky-rocket with upcoming planned large surveys and the next generation thirty-meter class telescopes, but we lack answers to even basic questions surrounding their evolution. This project investigates the physical processes at work in a unique set of dwarfs caught in the act of merging. Since Los Angeles, the hub for this program, is known more for its traffic than for its clear skies, the investigators will develop a traveling planetarium program. This program will be run by undergraduates and it will bring science to those who normally would not have access to such an outreach program. Audiences will include low income, predominantly minority groups, while encouraging the students involved to become leaders in their academic and local communities.

This project leverages the first systematic study of interacting dwarf galaxies, TiNy Titans, to investigate the impact of dwarf-dwarf interactions on galaxy evolution at all mass scales through a set of multiwavelength observations. Specifically, the project will produce the first comprehensive data sets of deep narrowband Halpha and broadband optical imaging, radio line and continuum maps of a large, systematically-selected sample of interacting dwarf galaxies and it will provide direct test of cosmological predictions. The main scientific goals of this project are aimed at quantifying the physical processes taking place in dwarf-dwarf interactions, including how star formation and gas processing behave in dwarf galaxies which are low metallicity, highly impacted by interactions, and may mirror conditions in the early universe. This project builds upon the extensive efforts by Occidental College to recruit underrepresented minority and first generation college-bound undergraduate students into science by providing these students with hands-on experience traveling to telescopes, conducting their own data reduction, and presenting their own results at national conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Tiny Titans (TNT) program is the first large-scale study of interacting dwarf galaxies through panchromatic observations. While mergers between massive galaxies, like our Milky Way, have been studied extensively, the merging together of smaller, so-called dwarf galaxies, remains mostly uncharted. Dwarf galaxies are fundamentally different than their massive counterparts so mergers between dwarf galaxies may proceed very differently. A major outcome of this work was to move beyond the individual examples that constituted the previous state of our knowledge of dwarf-dwarf galaxy mergers and towards an understanding of these systems as a class of galaxy.

Science Result: Dwarf pairs with TNT selection criteria are bound and interacting. To study merging dwarf galaxies, we must first successfully identify a sample of such mergers. The TNT dwarf mergers were originally identified in optical images as dwarf galaxies in close proximity to each other. A major outcome of this program was to obtain maps of the gas in the TNT pairs that show evidence of interaction more readily than the stars in the original optical images. The tidal tails and bridges seen in the gas maps show that the selection criteria used for identifying the original TNT sample in the optical images are successful at finding truly interacting dwarf galaxies. An example is shown in one of the provided figures.

Science Result: Additional dwarf galaxies can be identified via their gas content. Understanding how our Milky Way formed requires understanding the formation history of our nearest galaxy neighbors, the interacting dwarf galaxies called the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds. Understanding whether even smaller nearby galaxies are satellites of the Milky Way like the Clouds are, or if they actually belong to the Clouds themselves, is a key piece of the puzzle. Recent studies of analogs of the Clouds outside the presence of a massive galaxy like the Milky Way have tried to determine if those dwarf pairs host their own satellite galaxies. These studies have used optical images and have given limited results. A major outcome of this program was to determine that we could search for such satellites of dwarf galaxies using radio gas maps. In one of the TNT pairs, we identified two previously unknown dwarf galaxies that were missed by optical studies but found easily in our gas maps. The results are presented in one of the provided figures.

Science Result: Active black holes are not readily found in interacting dwarf galaxies. When massive galaxies merge, they are known to grow supermassive black holes, so we tested the hypothesis that mergers between dwarf galaxies could grow intermediate mass black holes. An analysis of the TNT interacting dwarf galaxies identified only eight possible intermediate mass black holes using optical, radio, X-ray, and infrared data. Thus mergers between dwarf galaxies must proceed differently than mergers between more massive galaxies, as they do not effectively grow their central black holes.

These scientific results were shared with the scientific community in over ten talks, including a plenary talk at the 2023 winter meeting of the American Astronomical Society for an audience of 3,000 people and an NSF Distinguished Lecture in March 2024.

Another major outcome of this project was the promotion of minoritized voices in STEM.

Successful Student Mentorship: Nine undergraduate summer research projects were funded by the program, all of which resulted in student presentations at national conferences including the annual meetings of the American Astronomical Society, the National Society for Black Physicists, and the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science. Eight of those nine students were from under-represented groups in astronomy. None of the students knew how to code or had participated in any research prior to beginning their projects so they were introduced to specific research techniques including how to find and read high level journal articles.

Long Term Recruitment of Under-represented Students into Astronomy: Two of those student researchers have already moved on to graduate school to pursue PhDs in physics and astrophysics. One student was awarded an NSF Graduate Fellowship with one of the reviewers crediting the quality of her research as the top reason for selecting her.

Traveling Planetarium Program Success: The PI trained seven undergraduate students to give shows in an inflatable planetarium for the diverse Los Angeles community that surrounds Occidental College. The students gave shows to over 500 people, including students from four Title I schools in the Los Angeles Unified School District, their families, and their teachers. Students wrote their own shows which incorporated images taken as part of the science component of the program.

Successful PI Support: The PI is a first generation student and woman in STEM. She is pre-tenure at Occidental College. The support of this grant and the successful science program it has enabled will be a major emphasis in her tenure case.
